Experimental and Clinical Psychopharmacology

INTRODUCTION

Crowdsourcing Methods in Addiction Science:

Emerging Research and Best Practices

Justin C. Strickland1, Michael Amlung2, 3, and Derek D. Reed2, 3

1 Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine

2 Department of Applied Behavioral Science, University of Kansas

3 Cofrin Logan Center for Addiction Research and Treatment, Lawrence, Kansas, United States

Crowdsourcing platforms such as Amazon Mechanical Turk, Proli\xef\xac\x81c, and Qualtrics Panels have become a
dominant form of sampling in recent years.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence: Crowdsourcing enables researchers to effectively and\nef\xef\xac\x81ciently sample research participants with greater geographic variability, access to hard-to-reach\npopulations, and reduced costs.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence: These methods have been increasingly used across varied areas of\npsychological science and essential for research during the COVID-19 pandemic due to their facilitation\nof remote research.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence: Recent work documents methods for improving data quality, emerging crowdsourcing\nplatforms, and how crowdsourcing data \xef\xac\x81t within broader research programs.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence:
Addiction scientists will bene\xef\xac\x81t
from the adoption of best practice guidelines in crowdsourcing as well as developing novel approaches,
venues, and applications to advance the \xef\xac\x81eld.

Public Health Signi\xef\xac\x81cance
The following set of articles in this special issue describes best practice methods and novel applications
of crowdsourcing in addiction and psychological science.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence:
These articles advance the \xef\xac\x81eld and present
practical guidelines and open-source resources for researchers using crowdsourcing in future work.

Keywords: crowdsourcing, methods, mTurk, Proli\xef\xac\x81c, validity

With the changing landscape of work amidst the global COVID-19
pandemic and increasing costs associated with collecting data from
large participant samples, researchers are turning to alternative meth-
ods for recruiting participants and collecting data.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence:
Accordingly,
crowdsourcing platforms such as Amazon Mechanical Turk, Proli\xef\xac\x81c,
and Qualtrics Panels have become a dominant form of sampling
in recent years (Strickland & Stoops, 2019).
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence:
These crowdsourcing
platforms enable researchers to continue to collect data from large
samples of human participants when face-to-face visits are challeng-
ing, cost-prohibitive, or infeasible due to other barriers (e.g., research
sites at logistically prohibitive distances; social distancing require-
ments during COVID-19).
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence:
Alongside optimism about the practical
bene\xef\xac\x81ts that crowdsourcing may provide are uncertainties about the
validity of these approaches and how they can (and cannot) be used.
This special issue includes a collection of articles on best practices and
emerging research using crowdsourcing for addictions research.

Articles included in this special issue emphasize that data quality
and control methods are critical in crowdsourcing platforms to
ensure data are reliable and valid.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence: Jones et al.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence:
(2022) summarize
the importance of this work using a meta-analysis of careless
responding in crowdsourced alcohol use research and \xef\xac\x81nd that
approximately 12% of participants are classi\xef\xac\x81ed as careless respon-
ders.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence:
They also provide practical recommendations to address these
issues to include the use of both overt and covert \xef\xac\x81delity measures.
Belliveau and Yakovenko (2022) complement these \xef\xac\x81ndings by
providing a practical implementation guide with step-by-step in-
structions for screening for speeding, straight-lining (i.e., tendency
to make the same response in a group of questions), inconsistent
responding, nonsensical responding, and missing data.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence: Open-source\ncode for conducting these procedures is provided for those looking\nto adopt these methods in their own work.

standing differentiated participants on consistency of cigarette use

As the methods to screen for quality data have improved, so have
the venues in which crowdsourcing has been applied.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence: Historically,\nAmazon Mechanical Turk was the primary crowdsourcing outlet for\npsychological and addiction science research.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence: Belliveau et al.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

(2022)
describe the use of the more recently developed Qualtrics Panels
resource to study behavioral addictions (video gaming and gaming
disorder).
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence: They \xef\xac\x81nd that Qualtrics data offered a participant pool\nsimilar in demographics to a community-recruited population sup-\nporting feasibility and potential usefulness of the resource.

sentence: (2022) show how another novel platform, Proli\xef\xac\x81c, can facilitate\nrepeated measures data in two protocols: a 5-day daily diary protocol\nand a test\xe2\x80\x93retest protocol.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence:
They explain across these two independent
studies how Proli\xef\xac\x81c-recruited participants provided valid data
consistent with theoretical expectations and afforded ef\xef\xac\x81cient
collection of longitudinal outcomes.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence: Beyond online platforms like\nAmazon Mechanical Turk, Qualtrics Panels, and Proli\xef\xac\x81c, Pennington\net al.

sentence: (2022) describe how big team science may ef\xef\xac\x81ciently crowd-\nsource researchers with the goal of producing reproducible projects\nconducted across varied institutions.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence:
A review of existing work using
big team, crowdsourced approaches (e.g., ManyLabs, Psychological
Science Accelerator) as well as a novel approach used by the study
team are described.

How crowdsourcing \xef\xac\x81ts within a broader research program is
ultimately varied and may include pilot projects, methods develop-
ment, intervention deployment, and more.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence: Rzeszutek et al.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence:
(2022)
provide one example of how crowdsourcing may be used to evaluate
novel behavioral outcomes by studying cross-drug withdrawal
effects for cigarette and opioids.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence:
They use a behavioral economic
framework to show that opioid withdrawal may increase cigarette
valuation, thereby providing a pathway for future treatment devel-
opment work to build upon.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence: Borodovsky (2022) integrates the above\nwork to describe differences between generalizability and represen-\ntativeness.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence:
A clear and concise review of these concepts is provided
along with how such differences may inform the boundary condi-
tions under which internet-based research may (or may not) advance
the literature.

Given the rapid emergence and evolution of crowdsourcing
research platforms, it is safe to assume this is a method that is here to
stay.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence: This special issue highlights best practices for using crowdsour-\ncing in addiction science while also drawing attention to important\nmethodological and conceptual limitations.
source: ContentServer.asp.pdf

sentence:
We hope that addiction

scientists continue to adhere to these guidelines while pushing the
boundaries of possible work within crowdsourcing science.

sentence:
b"1 

The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Science 

Authors: Patrick S. Forscher1,2, Eric-Jan Wagenmakers3, Nicholas A. Coles4,  

Miguel Alejandro Silan5,6, Nat\xc3\xa1lia Dutra7, Dana Basnight-Brown8, & Hans IJzerman2,9 

 
Affiliations: 
1Busara Center for Behavioral Economics 
2Universit\xc3\xa9 Grenoble Alpes 
3University of Amsterdam 
4Stanford University 
5Universit\xc3\xa9 Lumi\xc3\xa8re Lyon 2 
6Annecy Behavioral Science Lab 
7Universidade Federal do Par\xc3\xa1 
8United States International University-Africa 
9Institut Universitaire de France 
 
Notes: PSF and HIJ wrote the first draft; all authors provided critical comments and revisions.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Conflict of Interest Statement: PSF, NAC, MAS, ND, DB, and HIJ are members of the 
Psychological Science Accelerator, a network of psychology research labs that conducts big 
team science projects.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Abstract: Progress in psychology has been frustrated by challenges concerning replicability, 
generalizability, strategy selection, inferential reproducibility, and computational reproducibility.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Although often discussed separately, these five challenges may share a common cause: 
insufficient investment of intellectual and non-intellectual resources into the typical psychology 
study.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: We suggest that the emerging emphasis on big team science can help address these \nchallenges by allowing researchers to pool their resources together to increase the amount \navailable for a single study.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
However, the current incentives, infrastructure, and institutions in 
academic science have all developed under the assumption that science is conducted by solo 
Principal Investigators and their dependent trainees, an assumption that creates barriers to 
sustainable big team science.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: We also anticipate that big team science carries unique risks, such \nas the potential for big team science organizations to be co-opted by unaccountable leaders, \nbecome overly conservative, and make mistakes at a grand scale.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Big team science organizations \nmust also acquire personnel who are properly compensated and have clear roles, raising risks \nrelated to mismanagement and a lack of financial sustainability.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: If researchers can manage its \nunique barriers and risks, big team science has the potential to spur great progress in psychology \nand beyond.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
\x0c2 

Despite decades of investment, progress in psychology has been slower than many 

scholars would like (Fanelli, 2010; Meehl, 1978; Newell, 1973).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The lack of progress is \nempirically supported by the results of replication studies.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Whether with the same population, 
setting, and materials (the replicability challenge; Klein et al., 2014; Open Science 
Collaboration, 2015) or after a change to one or more of these features (the generalizability 
challenge; Henrich et al., 2010; Tiokhin et al., 2019; Yarkoni, 2019), replicated results often 
differ meaningfully from original results.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Meaningful differences also occur in other forms of 
replication, such as: when separate teams develop research strategies to address the same 
research question (the strategy selection challenge; Landy et al., 2020) when separate teams 
develop analysis plans for the same dataset (the inferential reproducibility challenge; Botvinik-
Nezer et al., 2019; Silberzahn et al., 2018), and even when separate teams write code to execute 
the same analysis (the computational reproducibility challenge; Donoho et al., 2008; Hardwicke 
et al., 2018; Obels et al., 2019).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nThese five challenges have complex proximal causes.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Yet they may share a common \n\nultimate cause: insufficient resource investment in the typical psychology study.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Insofar as this \npremise is true, a particular method of collaboration, big team science, may help address this \nultimate cause by efficiently scaling up the resources that can be invested in any given study.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: We \ndefine big team science as a method involving a relatively large number of collaborators who \nmay be dispersed across labs, institutions, disciplines, cultures, and continents.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: We contrast this \nsystem of science with small team science, which is usually organized around a single Principal \nInvestigator and their dependent trainees.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: If the unique risks and challenges of big team science \nare properly understood and managed, this method of collaboration may have great potential to \nimprove the efficiency and information value of psychological science.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
The challenges in psychology share a common cause 

Discussion of the slow progress in psychology has a long history.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Scholars have argued 
persuasively that each of the five challenges facing psychology has a pernicious and potentially 
destructive influence on scientific progress (Donoho et al., 2008; Landy et al., 2020; Meehl, 
1978; Sears, 1986; Silberzahn et al., 2018).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
These scholars have also presented a dizzying array 
of remedies for these challenges, ranging from increasing study sample sizes (Button et al., 
2013), which ought to improve replicability, to implementing version control (Vuorre & Curley, 
2018), which ought to improve computational reproducibility.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Although varied, these remedies 
share a common feature: they ask researchers to incur additional costs to improve a particular 
aspect of study rigor (Finkel et al., 2017; LeBel et al., 2017; see Table 1 for a list of proposed 
remedies and their attendant costs).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Because the individual researcher incurs costs for each remedy, discussions of problems 

in psychology tend to assume that implementations of these remedies are zero-sum in the 
following sense.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The scientific resources that are available to a given researcher, such as time, \nlabor, and money, are limited.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
This means that, as long as a solution to improve, say, replicability 
does not also improve all the other aspects of study rigor, resources devoted to implementing that 
solution to replicability must necessarily take away resources that could be spent on solutions to 
other aspects of rigor.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Replicability, generalizability, inferential reproducibility, strategy 
selection, and computational reproducibility thus become qualities that must be traded off each 

 

\x0c3 

other because devoting resources to improve one of these five qualities means sacrificing 
resources that could be invested in improving the others.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Five challenges in psychology and some proposed remedies for these challenges.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The challenges all ask \nresearchers to bear extra costs to improve some aspect of study rigor.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
\x0c4 

We suggest that the views that prioritize one aspect of rigor over the others all share an 
important, mistaken assumption: the pool of resources available for investment in a given study 
is fixed.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: If the resources devoted to a single study are not fixed, these resources may be raised to \na level that is high enough that no tradeoffs are necessary among the various types of research \nrigor.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Instead, a researcher need merely select as many of the rigor-enhancing strategies from \nTable 1 as they like and invest the money, human resources, and skills required to deploy those \nstrategies.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Thus, although they are often discussed separately, all five of psychology\xe2\x80\x99s major 

problems may share a common cause: under-investment of resources, whether those resources 
are money, person-hours, or specialized expertise, in psychology studies (see also Cuccolo et al., 
2021; Uhlmann et al., 2019).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Instead of asking which aspects of study rigor ought to be 
prioritized, reframing psychology\xe2\x80\x99s problems from this perspective allows us to ask a different 
question: how can we increase the resources invested in psychology studies and ascertain that the 
extra investment is used efficiently?
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Increasing resource investment through big team science organizations 

Increasing the per-study resource investment across an entire research ecosystem faces a 

collective action problem: as long as scientists are rewarded for publishing more studies, any 
single scientist who decides to invest more resources in fewer studies will be outcompeted by 
scientists who invest less resources in more studies (Smaldino & McElreath, 2016).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Any attempt 
to increase the per-study resource investment of the entire ecosystem must adopt one of two 
solutions: (1) directly change the institutional incentives that prioritize quantity of publication 
and/or (2) devise new institutions, which we call big team science organizations, that allow blocs 
of scientists to increase the resource investments in concert.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Direct change in the institutions of science is difficult because science itself has a 

decentralized structure \xe2\x80\x93 changing its reward structures requires buy-in from many independent 
actors.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: This limits the effectiveness of initiatives to directly change the incentives that prioritize \nquantity of publication.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: A similar problem afflicts the establishment of new organizations that \ncoordinate the efforts of scientists to jointly invest in single projects.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Fortunately, new 
information and communication technologies, such as the Google suite of collaboration tools, the 
Open Science Framework, Slack, and Zoom, have made the establishment of such organizations 
more feasible because they permit rapid, low-cost communication across far-flung countries and 
circumstances (Teasley & Wolinsky, 2001).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Such communication lays the groundwork for new \ninstitutions that can change how scientific actors spend resources on their science (Spellman, \n2015).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
The function of an organization is to coordinate the activities of many actors 

simultaneously.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: An organization solves the collective action problem faced by individual actors \nby allowing multiple actors to pre-commit to a coordinated, simultaneous course of action.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
In the 
context of science, a big team science organization allows many scientists to pre-commit to 
investing their limited scientific resources into one big project in exchange for an individual 
reward \xe2\x80\x93 usually, authorship on a publication, though other rewards are possible, such as money 
or networking opportunities.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
During the project itself, the organization coordinates the actions of 

 

\x0c5 

the scientists so that they do not work at cross-purposes.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: These functions allow the per-study \ninvestments from big team science projects to eclipse what is achievable in small team science.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
We believe that the primary and most definitional function of a big team science 

organization is to allow larger investments of material and intellectual resources in a given 
project.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: However, once established, big team science organizations have the potential to provide \nbenefits to both individual scientists and the broader scientific ecosystem that are external to this \nprimary function.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: As an example of one such positive externality, big team science organizations \ncentralize many aspects of project administration in one organization rather than forcing \nindividual labs to complete these functions on their own.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
This not only produces an efficiency for 
the scientific ecosystem, but also allows researchers at organizations without strong research 
infrastructure, such as instructors at teaching-focused universities (Wagge, Baciu, et al., 2019; 
Wagge, Brandt, et al., 2019) to do more research than would otherwise be possible.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Big teams 
also allow individual researchers to specialize into roles that match their skills rather than 
occupying all roles simultaneously, producing an efficiency for the scientific ecosystem and 
giving the individual researcher the opportunity to develop a specialized skill and thereby 
command a higher salary.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Researchers who join a big team science organization also gain access \nto an expansive community.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: For the individual researcher, this reduces intellectual isolation and \nopens the door to professional opportunities; for the scientific ecosystem, this can generate new \ncollaborations that would not have been possible absent the expansive community.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Finally, if big \nteam science organizations become robust enough, they can become political actors of their own \nright within the broader scientific ecosystem.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Thus, they can nudge the incentives and values of \nthe entire scientific ecosystem by, for example, prioritizing the qualities of scientists to improve \nteam productivity rather than individual productivity (Tiokhin et al., 2021).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Thus, big team science organizations can invest more resources into individual projects 

than is possible in small teams.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Big team science organizations also have the potential to provide \na variety of benefits to individual researchers and the broader scientific ecosystem that are \nexternal to this primary function.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Whether these benefits materialize depend on establishing the \norganizations in the first place and ensuring the organizations do not fall prey to some of the \nunique risks and challenges of this style of science.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Big team science outside of psychology 

Some disciplines have already adopted a big team science model, so they can provide 

useful examples of how big team science organizations can arise.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: These examples can also \nillustrate whether big team science can address the limitation of under-resourced studies.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: In the \n1990s, behavioral genetics generally featured small studies examining the relationship between \nvariation in a single candidate gene and a complex behavior or trait.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
In one prominent example, 
only 52 patients provided genetic material for an analysis of the relationship between the 5-
HTTLPR polymorphism and major depression (Heils et al., 1996), a finding that spurred 
enormous interest in the biological mechanisms through which these genes might cause 
depression (Dannlowski et al., 2008; Gotlib et al., 2008).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Unfortunately, and similar to the \ncurrent situation in psychology, these early results were contradicted by failed replication studies \n(Gillespie et al., 2005).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: As more and more replication studies contradicted the earlier optimistic \nones, researchers in behavioral genetics realized that changes were in order (Rieckmann, 2009).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
\x0c6 

The two decades that followed were a turning point for behavioral genetics because they 
gave rise to big team science in the form of large research consortia.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Without pooling resources, \nresearchers would have been unable to attain the scale of data necessary to advance our \nunderstanding of behavioral genetics.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Before these consortia could attain such large-scale data, 
they needed to invest considerable research, time, and funds devising methodological workflows 
(Corvin et al., 2010), designing infrastructure to manage and harmonize datasets (Sullivan, 
2010), and developing processes that increased the accuracy of the measurement of genotypes 
and phenotypes (23andMe Research Team et al., 2018; Corvin et al., 2010).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
With these solutions 
in hand, the research consortia served as a conduit through which multiple labs pooled resources 
to achieve large, heterogeneous samples that would otherwise have been out of reach for any 
single lab working independently.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The UK Biobank is a prominent example, hosting a repository \nfor data from over 500,000 participants, a sample that dwarfs the sample of 52 used for the first \n5-HTTLPR study.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The resulting findings have revolutionized our understanding of genes and \nbehavior: we now know that, instead of single genetic variants exerting large influences, a large \nnumber of variants have small influences (23andMe Research Team et al., 2018).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: These impacts \nwere subtle enough that they could not be observed and studied using the small, homogeneous \nsamples typically employed in the early 1990s.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Innovations in methods, workflows, and \nmeasurement allowed for a sea change in our understanding of the relationship between genes \nand behavior.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nParticle physics provides another, still larger-scale, example.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
The 1950s saw a growing 

recognition among particle physicists that further advances would require a scale of research and 
equipment that would strain the budgets of entire nations, let alone single laboratories (Krige, 
2004).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
For their part, Western governments saw cooperative large-scale investments in physics 
as a potential diplomatic tool; the projects served as a highly visible counterweight growing 
Soviet power, demonstrating the benefits that could accrue from an internationalist, democratic, 
and cooperative world order (Krige, 2004).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: These twin recognitions spurred the establishment of \n\xe2\x80\x9cmega-collaborations\xe2\x80\x9d: large, international collaborations spanning multiple countries.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Such 
mega-collaborations could only realize their aims through both technical and social 
achievements to establish the infrastructure, documentation, and workflows necessary to 
coordinate the efforts of huge numbers of scientists (Bakker, 1955; Brumfiel, 2011; for a modern 
workflow, see Espinosa et al., 2020).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
One of the pre-eminent examples of these mega-
collaborations is the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN), which, together with 
Brookhaven National Laboratory, helped usher in a new era of particle physics: high-energy 
physics, in which large teams of scientists harness vast resources to probe the most fundamental 
constituents of matter (Bryant, 1994).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
\x0c7 

 

Name 

Type

Reproducibility Project: Psychology 
(Open Science Collaboration, 2015) 

Ad-hoc 

A large team-science project in psychology, which involved 270 
contributing authors, who replicated 100 effects.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
ManyLabs (Ebersole et al., 2016; Klein et 
al., 2014, 2018, 2019) 

Ad-hoc 

These projects involve dozens of researchers, each of whom collects 
data using their own local resources.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The individual datasets are pooled \nto create a large common dataset.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Many Smiles Collaboration (Coles et 
al., 2019) 

Ad-hoc 

A collaborative project designed to find the best way to test the 
hypothesis that facial expressions influence emotions.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The test was \ndeveloped through consensus design.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The resulting design uses multiple \noperationalizations and will be tested in a multi-site study.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Research contests to reduce implicit 
race preferences (Lai et al., 2014, 2016) 

Ad-hoc 

A series of contests to develop the most effective interventions to 
reduce implicit race preferences.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Separate teams submitted \ninterventions; all interventions were run together on a large online \nplatform.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Registered Replication Reports (Simons 
et al., 2014) 

Standing 

An initiative to conduct multi-lab, preregistered close replications of 
previous studies.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The initiative supervised by a hosting journal.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \nOriginally initiated at Perspectives at Psychological Science, other \njournals have adopted similar initiatives.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Exact policies differ across \njournals.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Collaborative Replication and 
Education Project (Wagge, Baciu, et al., 
2019; Wagge, Brandt, et al., 2019) 

Standing 

A framework for engaging undergraduates in replication research.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: On \nconsultation with student advisors, the CREP team selects target effects \nfor replication.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: CREP develops a set of templates that guide the \nreplication process and uses a team of reviewers to ensure that the \nmethods for each individual lab are true to the template.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Psychological Science Accelerator 
(Jones et al., 2021; Moshontz et al., 
2018) 

ManyBabies (Byers-Heinlein et al., 
2020) 

Standing 

A standing, democratically structured network of labs focused on 
improving the national diversity of psychology samples.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Standing 

A standing network that conducts multi-site infancy research.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Table 2.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Eight big team science initiatives in psychology.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Big team science in psychology 

Psychology has also started to witness an increase in big team science projects.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Although 

most of these projects are recent, they have already had an outsized impact on the field (see 
Table 2 for details).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: However, these efforts have revealed three categories of obstacles that must \nbe overcome if big team science is to maintain a sustained presence in the research landscape.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
These obstacles are: incentivizing labor within the collaboration; developing and maintaining 
infrastructure to coordinate team science activities; and dealing with institutions designed 
around research conducted by smaller teams.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
\x0cBarrier 

Description 

Solutions 

Incentives 

Academic prestige goes 
disproportionately to the first-listed 
author on publications 

Consortium authorship 

Contributorship systems, like CRediT 

8

Coordinating team science requires 
dedicated infrastructure 

Google Suite of tools for general online collaboration

Zoom and other videoconferencing for online meetings 

formr for online deployment of big team science projects 

experimentum for building experiments and managing projects

Big team science must navigate 
frictions created by institutional

source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Barriers to big team science and some potential solutions.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nIncentives.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Due to the central importance of prestige in obtaining academic rewards, \n\nacademics are incentivized to obtain publications that can be used to enhance their prestige.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
This 
means that any collective research enterprise that wishes to direct the labor of academic scientists 
must either rely on sporadic volunteerism, find some other reward, like money, that substitute for 
prestige, or find a way to dole out prestige.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: We describe the risks of relying on volunteerism and \nthe barriers to providing money as a reward in the sections on institutional barriers and risks of \nfinancial unsustainability.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Here we deal more completely with prestige as a form of \ncompensation.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
A central problem with prestige as an incentive for participation in big team science is 

that, under the current system for awarding credit for publications, the bulk of credit goes to the 
first-listed author.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: This reward structure does not effectively incentivize the labor of the \nnumerous other people who are necessary to produce big team science publications.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Moreover, 
big team science organizations must do a tremendous amount of administration and coordination 
that, while critical to the success of the collaboration as a whole, is not easily creditable on 
publications.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nWe see at least two innovations that may help resolve this problem.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
The first is 

consortium authorship, in which a publication is credited to a collective entity rather than a 
group of individuals, or in which all members of the collaboration are listed alphabetically on all 
publications to render the individual subservient to the collective (Birnholtz, 2008).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
This was the 
approach to credit taken by the Open Science Collaboration when they published the 

 

 

\x0c9 

Reproducibility Project: Psychology (Open Science Collaboration, 2015).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
This is also the 
approach taken by some large physics collaborations, especially for papers that document details 
of infrastructure or instrumentation (e.g., ALICE collaboration, 2010; Harry & the LIGO 
Scientific Collaboration, 2010; The ATLAS collaboration et al., 2018).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: This innovation \nincentivizes collaboration by attempting to flatten the credit reward structure.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Consortium 
authorship systems come at some risk, however: they can under-reward highly active but less 
visible consortium members, or lead consortium members to seek informal routes of gaining 
recognition, thereby effectively substituting the flat, formal system of credit with a more 
arbitrary informal system (Birnholtz, 2008).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
The second innovation is to disclose contributions in a more fine-grained way through 

contributorship systems, such as CRediT (McNutt et al., 2018).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: These systems allow contributors \nto list within a manuscript the specific roles contributors play in projects.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
In principle, 
contributorship systems should allow people to develop reputations for filling certain types of 
project roles, such as data analysis or project management, and they should allow more fine-
grained accountability when errors are detected in the project.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Finally, contributorship systems \nenable contributors to provide evidence of excellence in a particular project role when applying \nfor grants, jobs, or other professional rewards.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
However, contributorship systems will only serve their purpose of giving recognition to 
excellent team scientists if people who control professional rewards, such as members of hiring 
committees, promotion committees, and funding committees, actually attend to and reward 
evidence of excellent team science contributions.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Although we see promise in contributorship 
systems as a method to incentivize big team science labor (Holcombe, 2019), the existence of 
contributorship information is by itself not sufficient to ensure that incentives are aligned to 
reward big team science labor.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The people who control professional rewards must also attend to \nthese systems if they are to serve their intended functions.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Infrastructure.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: A second obstacle is the need for infrastructure to help facilitate and \ncoordinate big team science projects.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Some of this infrastructure already exists, such as the \nSlack, Google suite of collaboration tools, and Zoom.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: This existing infrastructure has been \ninstrumental in propelling big team science to where it is today.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
For example, projects run 
through the Psychological Science Accelerator (Moshontz et al., 2018) use a combination of 
Slack and email for project coordination, Google Docs, Sheets, and Forms for collaborative 
project workflows (for a writing worklow, see Moshontz et al., 2019), a shared Google Drive for 
collaborative files management, and Zoom for conference calls.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: However, this existing \ninfrastructure is general-purpose and therefore does not fully meet the specialized needs of \nbehavioral science.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: For example, most psychology data collection platforms are designed for use \nby one or two users.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: This is insufficient in a team of researchers numbering in the hundreds.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Although not every researcher needs to be part of the development of, for example, a survey, 
multiple users need to access survey instruments when helping with translation or other parts of 
the survey development process.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Another example of where research infrastructure is insufficient is when recruiting 
samples of participants that vary linguistically \xe2\x80\x93 a common occurrence when working with 
worldwide collaborators.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Often, translated versions of the target measures are simply \nunavailable.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Creating and validating a greater array of translated measure versions will go a long 

 

\x0c10 

way toward facilitating big team science projects.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: A lack of applicability across languages and \ncountries apply to infrastructure across all stages of the research lifecycle.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Data collection and \nmanagement platforms in particular must cope with both issues involving language and \ntranslation and the varying ethical and legal standards that govern private data.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Fortunately, some promising initiatives already exist that, if they are properly supported, 
may help resolve these more specialized problems.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: For example, the formr experiment platform \n(Arslan et al., 2019) relies on some of the infrastructure that is already in place, namely Google \nSheets, to permit easy, flexible, and collaborative construction of online experiments.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Another 
promising project in this vein is the experimentum framework (https://psa.psy.gla.ac.uk/), which 
aims to develop an experiment builder and project management framework that is specialized for 
large, cross-linguistic, big team science settings.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Finally, the ScienceVerse project (Lakens & \nDeBruine, 2021) aims to create a fully functional \xe2\x80\x9cgrammar of science\xe2\x80\x9d that can be used for \nnaming, describing, and identifying relationships between components of any scientific project.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Such a grammar would be especially helpful for highly collaborative, cross-linguistic, big team 
science projects that must document a large number of components while navigating specialized 
ethical and legal standards.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
These initiatives will only succeed in meeting the specialized infrastructure needs of big 

team science in the social sciences if they are supported financially and on a sustainable basis.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \nFunders should recognize that these and other initiatives that support big team science also \nprovide benefits for small team science.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: For example, although formr is especially useful in team \nsettings, it provides a useful platform for teams of any size.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Smart and ongoing investment in \nthese projects will go a long way toward facilitating both small team and big team science.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nInstitutions.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Another set of obstacles relates to the institutions that have developed \nassuming that projects are led by a solo (or small number of) Principal Investigators.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: These \ninstitutions cause friction in almost every aspect of large, collaborative science.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The frictions \nstart with funding mechanisms, most of which assume that projects are led by a sole PI and their \nstaff.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The European Research Council\xe2\x80\x99s Consolidator Grant, for example, supports a single PI \nand their host institution, and the European Research Council enforces highly detailed \naccounting rules to ensure all money is used in support of a solo PI\xe2\x80\x99s project.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: As another \nexample, some grant funders, such as the US National Science Foundation, require applicants to \nlist all their collaborators from a specified time period.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: This requirement places burdensome \nrestrictions on prospective big team scientists whose collaborators can easily number in the \nhundreds.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Even once money is awarded, administrative and legal barriers can make it difficult to \nsend the money to the institutions and countries where it is needed.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nSimilar frictions plague almost every part of the big team science research lifecycle.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Academic psychology departments do not typically train scientists to operate in large, distributed 
team settings and do not have specialized training tracks for scientists who wish to specialize in 
the many specific roles that big team science requires.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Ethical Review Boards are often not \nprepared to evaluate a project that will be executed at a hundred sites worldwide.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
A big team 
science project with 100 collaborating labs may need to submit 100 variations of the same 
application to 100 Ethical Review Boards \xe2\x80\x93 a process that leads to immense waste and 
duplication of effort (Ervin et al., 2016; Schneider, 2015, pg.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf
Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Even the content of ethical \nregulations themselves differs across locations due to varying laws and norms.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Some 

 

\x0c11 

organizations are not subject to clear ethical requirements at all \xe2\x80\x93 or, as is the case in East Africa, 
for example \xe2\x80\x93 they are only able to complete an ethical review in exchange for a costly fee that 
competes with other research costs (Kaplay, 2016; Osborne & Luoma, 2018).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
As another example, journal submission portals are built assuming that articles are 

written by a relatively small number of authors \xe2\x80\x93 not 200 \xe2\x80\x93 and the process of entering author 
information is cumbersome and wasteful.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: A similar barrier obstructs the entry of authorship \ninformation in preprint servers like PsyArXiv.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Once research is complete, tenure and evaluation \ncommittees do not know how to evaluate publications with hundreds of authors.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
This decision is 
high stakes, because if researchers that prioritize big team science are penalized by these 
committees, these \xe2\x80\x9cbig team scientists\xe2\x80\x9d will be effectively selected out of the ecology of science 
(Smaldino & McElreath, 2016).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nHere we are less certain what the future holds.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
If the institutions of psychological science 

adapt to the emergence of big team science, they will make this sort of science less costly and 
therefore more common.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Alternatively, psychological science could develop an entirely new set \nof institutions, such as funders, ethical review boards, and journals, that are more \naccommodating of big team science.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Whatever the future may hold, we hope that the institutions \nof science recognize the potential of big team science and act accordingly.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Risks of big team science 

Although we believe that big team science approaches have great promise, they also 

 
bring a unique set of risks that stem from the very feature that provides their main benefits: the 
fact that they coordinate and centralize resources to be deployed in a single project (Stokols et 
al., 2008).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: These risks are unaccountable leadership, management failures, conservatism, \nsustainability failures, and mega-mistakes.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nUnaccountable leadership.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The primary virtue of big team science is its ability to deploy \n\nresources at a large scale.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Often, this requires turning over resources to a single scientific 
organization, which carries the same risk as that entailed in turning over resources to a single 
governmental organization: the leadership of that organization could use the resources to 
centralize power within themselves and make themselves unaccountable to influence and 
criticism.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
The negative consequences of unaccountable leadership power can impact many features 
of the scientific process.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: For example, in the idea generation phase, unaccountable leadership can \nselect their own pet topics for investigation without heeding the ideas of people with less power, \nleading to ideas that are less creative and impactful (Wu et al., 2019).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Unaccountable leadership \ncan also stifle diversity in the strategies that are selected to develop and test the ideas that are \nselected (Devezer et al., 2019), slowing the pace of discovery.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Finally, unaccountable leadership 
can have negative consequences for individual scholars who do not conform to leadership\xe2\x80\x99s 
perhaps narrow expectations of who is a proper \xe2\x80\x9cbig team scientist\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x93 especially if the leadership 
has influence over important mechanisms of career advancement (Azoulay et al., 2019).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
\x0c12 

Risk 

Description 

Mitigation strategies 

Unaccountable leadership 

Leadership of big team science 
organizations make themselves 
unaccountable to influence and 
criticism 

Articulate organizational values 

Create structured bylaws 

Introduce democratic accountability 

Empower a board of directors 

Articulate roles and responsibilities 

Management failures 

Big team science organizations 
involve large numbers of 
relationships, and navigating the 
interpersonal issues that arise 
requires effective management of 
people 

Create structured methods of making decisions 

Create formal and informal ways to solicit team member feedback 

Obtain formal management training 

Proactively partner with organizations that serve underrepresented groups 

Conservatism 

Create mechanisms to facilitate mobility and advancement within the team 

Big team science organizations 
may make decisions that cater to 
the median desire of the people in 
their group
