Big team science organizations 
require planning to be financially 
sustainable over the long term 

Mega-mistakes 

When big team science 
organizations make mistakes, they 
tend to be big ones 

Table 4.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Risks of team science and some risk mitigation strategies.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Separate idea generation from project implementation 

Pay people the people who are responsible for the organization's 
maintenance 

Create and follow a sustainability plan 

Mitigate the other four types of risk 

Institute pro-active quality control processes 

Mitigating this risk.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: At a baseline, big team science organizations should have a set of \n\nbylaws that lay out who is empowered to do what and a set of values.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The bylaws need not \nspecify a completely de-centralized power structure.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Centralizing power within a small number 
of leaders can have important benefits, such as enabling those leaders to develop a coherent 
organizational strategy and allowing those leaders to make fast, agile decisions to adjust that 
strategy (Baum & Wally, 2003).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
However, to mitigate the risk of a lack of accountability, 
centralization of leadership must be accompanied with mechanisms to hold leadership 
accountable for its decisions if those leaders pursue directions with which important stakeholders 
disagree.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
An important tool for enabling such accountability is a clearly articulated statement of the 
values that guide the big team science organization\xe2\x80\x99s mission.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Once articulated, these values can 

 

\x0c13 

allow the organization\xe2\x80\x99s stakeholders to identify leadership mistakes that might require 
accountability by allowing those stakeholders to evaluate whether leadership actions do indeed 
fit with the organization\xe2\x80\x99s values.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Insofar as leaders do issue regular statements about their \norganizational strategy, a set of well-articulated values also allows stakeholders to evaluate \nwhether that strategy is indeed pursuing those values.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
However, values are empty unless a group of organization stakeholders are empowered to 

take action if and when leaders violate those values.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: One example of an empowered stakeholder \nis a board of directors that is empowered by the organization\xe2\x80\x99s bylaws to remove leaders with \nwhom they are unsatisfied.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: This board of directors should receive regular updates on the status of \nthe big team science organization so that they can ask leaders to make corrections before a crisis \noccurs.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Another possibility is to introduce explicit democratic mechanisms into the organization, \nsuch as regular elections for leadership positions.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Whatever the form, accountability must be \nbuilt into the organization\xe2\x80\x99s structure if it is to effectively check the risks of unaccountable \nleadership.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nManagement failures.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The number of relationships within a team increases \n\ncombinatorially with the number of people within the team.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Larger teams also create more \nopportunities for people with widely different backgrounds to collide \xe2\x80\x93 or for single trouble-\nmakers to create a toxic environment.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Finally, larger teams are more likely to be characterized by \nspecialized roles and communication channels.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: These features vastly increase the complexity of \nrelationships in very large teams.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: In failure cases, this complexity can lead to management \nfailures.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nThe first of these failures is role ambiguity.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Role ambiguity occurs when the information 

a person has about the expectations that go along with the role, the methods for fulfilling those 
expectations, and the consequences for violating those expectations are unclear (Van Sell et al., 
1981).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Role ambiguity can occur in small groups, but the number of roles in a large scientific \nteam, combined with the specialization of roles and complex decision-making apparatus, \nincrease the risk of role ambiguity as teams increase in size.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Role ambiguity increases the risk of \nerrors because team members are uncertain which responsibilities apply to them.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: This \nuncertainly can lead to duplicated work on the one hand and unfulfilled tasks on the other.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Role \nambiguity also breeds feelings of dissatisfaction, leading people to grow disillusioned with the \nbig team science organization and, in extreme failure cases, to leave it (Tubre & Collins, 2000).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nThe second failure is ineffective management of interpersonal issues.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Some interpersonal 

issues, such as conflict between team members, are inevitable due simply to the number of 
relationships involved in big team science organizations.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Some level of conflict can even be \nconstructive when it is managed properly and kept task-focused (Forsyth, 2014; Loughry & \nAmason, 2014; Rahim, 2003).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: However, conflict can also create organizational dysfunction, \npotentially polarizing the team and derailing entire projects (Rahim, 2003).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
In the presence of 
sharp power differences between team members and unclear mechanisms for accountability, 
conflict can also take on a darker guise in the form of harassment and abuse (Berdahl & Raver, 
2011).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The risks of conflict can be especially high when team members have sharp cultural or \nepistemic differences, as might be expected in big team science settings that bring together \npeople of varying personal, cultural, and disciplinary backgrounds (Bender et al., 2015).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
\x0c14 

Mitigating this risk.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
The most fundamental step a big team science organization can take 

to mitigate the risk of organizational failures is to establish a well-defined leadership structure 
that clearly communicates and enforces the organization\xe2\x80\x99s roles and decisions (Stokols, 2006).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \nThe leadership structure should also create both formal and informal ways of soliciting feedback \nfrom members of the big team science organization.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
These feedback mechanisms should include 
a means to report problematic behavior by individual team members, along with a means to hold 
problematic team members accountable, such as reporting the behavior to the team member\xe2\x80\x99s 
workplace.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The feedback mechanisms should establish a feedback loop between decision-makers \nand team members so that the organization responds effectively to issues as they arise.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
The goal 
of the feedback loop will not eliminate interpersonal issues, as some number of issues are simply 
part of the human condition, but rather to instill a sense that procedures are fair when issues do 
occur (Konovsky, 2000).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Effective communication also fosters an environment of psychological \nsafety in which team members feel empowered to express issues, concerns, and points of \ndisagreement without creating outright fights (Frazier et al., 2017).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nClarifying roles and instilling psychological safety both take time.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
However, their 

importance to effective collaboration means that team science organizations should prioritize 
creating structures that allow transparent communication, decision-making, and enforcement, 
ideally through a formal collaboration agreement that is drafted before the collaboration begins.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Structured methods of communication, decision-making, and enforcement lay the groundwork to 
allow team members to build the mutual trust that is necessary for collaboration (Astuti & Bloch, 
2012).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nManagement of teams is a vital skill that is seldom taught in the academy.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Universities 

should recognize the central role that management plays in the success of projects, especially the 
larger ones that typify big team science.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: If big team science is to take root in the social sciences, \nmanagement training needs to become a central part of the behavioral science curriculum.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nConservatism.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Large organizations require large amounts of people to keep themselves \nrunning.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: If these organizations attempt to satisfy the desires of these large numbers of people, \nthey will tend to cater to the median desire.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: This means that organizations will usually be \nconservative \xe2\x80\x93 or at least conservative with respect to the people within the group.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: This \nconservatism can manifest in two ways: in the selection of personnel and the selection of \nprojects.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
People tend to form social relationships with others who have similar characteristics and 

backgrounds (Kossinets & Watts, 2009; McPherson et al., 2001).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Given that contemporary 
psychology is dominated by North America and Europe (Rad et al., 2018; Thalmayer et al., 
2020), this raises a risk that big team science organizations will be similarly dominated by people 
from those continents.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: For example, not a single first author of the papers in Table 2 comes from \na nation outside North America and Europe.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Once big team science organizations dominated by \nNorth America and Europe are established, they may inadvertently crowd out organizations from \nelsewhere with different goals and personnel.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Systematically excluding large subsets of humanity \nfrom psychology perpetuates unfair systems of inequality and can lead to a science that focuses \nunduly on the preoccupations of a small subset of humanity (Medin et al., 2017).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
\x0c15 

Conservatism can also manifest in project selection.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The primary purpose of big team \nscience is to scale up the resources that can be invested in a given project.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
However, this very 
virtue may induce big team science collaborations to select projects that they perceive as \xe2\x80\x9csafe\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x93 
both in terms of whether they can be feasibly executed and in terms of the degree to which they 
deviate from the scientific mainstream.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Given that some degree of theoretical risk is necessary to \nspur scientific progress (Devezer et al., 2019; Meehl, 1978), this theoretical conservatism could \nfeasibly slow scientific progress.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nMitigating this risk.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
To mitigate the risk of conservatism in personnel selection, we can 

draw on a general slate of strategies to improve the inclusion of underrepresented groups in 
science (Enriquez, 1979; Henrich et al., 2010; Syed & Kathawalla, 2020).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: These solutions must \nbegin at the start of big team science organizations and must be continually re-evaluated \nthroughout the organization\xe2\x80\x99s lifecycle.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
At the organization\xe2\x80\x99s founding, the founders must 
proactively and systematically partner with researchers in a broad array of non-Western and non-
elite institutions \xe2\x80\x93 and especially those who are not part of the \xe2\x80\x9cvirtual academic commons\xe2\x80\x9d 
formed by Twitter, Facebook, and science blogs.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Once the organization has been founded, the \norganization\xe2\x80\x99s leadership must create mechanisms that allow for mobility within the team so that \nmembers of underrepresented groups can rise to positions of leadership.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: However, even these \nmeasures will not be sustainable without the direct investment of material resources into research \ninfrastructure in under-resourced world regions.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Diversity in big team science personnel will not ensure diversity in big team science 

projects.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Mitigating the risk of this type of conservatism requires maintaining a separation \nbetween the idea generation and the project implementation phases of big team science projects.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \nDuring the idea generation phase, much smaller groups of scientists can identify problems and \napproaches unconstrained from a broader team consensus.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The smaller teams then develop \nproposals based on their ideas and submit them for consideration by the larger consortium.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
The 
larger team can even explicitly build in mechanisms to solicit proposals from teams whose 
perspectives may differ from the scientific mainstream \xe2\x80\x93 such as those from outside North 
America and Europe.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nSustainability failures.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The history of science is littered with promising initiatives and \n\norganizations that, once established, could not be sustained (Borgman et al., 2016).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: This problem \nrecurs so frequently because scientific organizations are typically public-minded: they wish to \nprovide a public good at little or no cost.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Yet, this very public-mindedness invites free-ridership \n\xe2\x80\x93 people who will use the organization\xe2\x80\x99s service but who are either unwilling or unable to \nsupport the organization financially (Neylon, 2017).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nThis dynamic also threatens big team science organizations.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: All the initiatives listed in \nTable 2 were formed because the founders thought that large-scale collaboration could lead to \nbetter science rather than out of a desire to make money.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: If the initiative is intended to last for a \nsingle project, the project could survive using an ad hoc organizational structure run on the back \nof volunteer labor.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: However, continually creating one-shot organizations is wasteful and \ninefficient because such a model prevents the accumulation of organizational knowledge.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
If an 
initiative is to last beyond a single project, its leadership must at some point figure out how to 
generate the money required to retain long-term staff while not compromising the vision that 
inspired the project in the first place.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
\x0c16 

Mitigating this risk.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The first step to mitigating the risk of a sustainability failure is to \n\nrecognize that organizations cannot support themselves for free.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
If we want to have organizations 
that are capable of coordinating very large groups of scientists, those organizations must receive 
financial support so that they can generate and maintain the knowledge, staff, and other scientific 
resources necessary to fulfill their function.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: A corollary of this dictum is that, over the long haul, \nat least some skilled positions in a big team science organization must receive monetary \ncompensation.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Running entirely on volunteerism risks exploiting the idealistic people willing to \ndonate their time (Kim et al., 2020), leading to burnout and interpersonal conflict.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
The second step to mitigating this risk involves creating and following a sustainability 
plan (for an example, see Forscher & IJzerman, 2021) that maps out how the organization will 
generate the funds necessary to maintain itself.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
The funding models could entail what is most 
familiar to academic scientists: designating some team members as grantwriters who spend part 
of their time identifying and applying for large grants to support the big team science 
organization.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: However, this grantwriting model puts big team science organizations at the whims \nof large funders, who are often only willing to spend money on projects that generate \ndiscoveries, not the infrastructure that makes the discoveries possible (Zakaria et al., 2021).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Most 
science grantmakers also rely on competitive peer review to select the most \xe2\x80\x9cworthy\xe2\x80\x9d projects, a 
funding model that risks inefficiency because it encourages grantwriters to spend more time on 
grants than the activities the grants would fund (Gross & Bergstrom, 2019).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: For these reasons, \nwe believe that a grantwriting-based funding model carries inherent risks of both research waste \nand instability in personnel due to feast-or-famine funding cycles.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
We believe that a more promising approach is to use one of the funding models that have 
led to sustainable funding for other large public-minded scientific organizations (Neylon, 2017).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
These funding models will likely involve either creating a system that \xe2\x80\x9ctaxes\xe2\x80\x9d all beneficiaries of 
the big team science infrastructure by, say, imposing membership dues rather as a scientific 
society does, or, alternatively providing the infrastructure as a byproduct of selling another 
service.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The other service could involve many things, but it should leverage what big team \nscience organizations already do well \xe2\x80\x93 running multi-site studies.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Thus, the organization might \nrun some multi-site studies for a fee, or it might sell a service that it has needed to perfect in \norder to run multi-site studies, such as translation or project management.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
We believe that all 
these options are viable, though each has their own tradeoffs; membership dues could make the 
big team science organization inaccessible to lower-resourced members, whereas selling services 
could introduce conflicts of interest that threaten the organization\xe2\x80\x99s mission.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Choosing and \nfollowing a sustainability plan is necessary to maintain any public-minded organization, but the \ntradeoffs of the available options must also be evaluated with care.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nMega-mistakes.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The final risk of big team science is that of what we term mega-mistakes.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Big team science\xe2\x80\x99s primary virtue is its ability to \xe2\x80\x9cscale up\xe2\x80\x9d small projects into big ones by 
pooling resources across labs.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: However, this very virtue makes errors all the more costly: these \nerrors risk wasting much more resources than would be wasted on a smaller project.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: These errors \ncan even occur at the time of project selection if the topic of the project is not one that deserves \nthe high investment of resources that big team science brings.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nErrors in big team projects often have no one simple cause.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Consider the example of the \n\nHuman Brain Project.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
This project aimed to unlock massive advances for neuroscience by 

 

\x0c17 

developing and building large-scale computer simulations of brain regions, and eventually of 
entire brains (Markram, 2012).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
The leader of the project, Henry Markram, set an ambitious 
agenda; in 2009, he claimed that, after only ten more years of development the technology that 
powered the project would allow the simulation of an entire rodent brain, an achievement that he 
believed would revolutionize neuroscience (Abbott, 2020).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The project\xe2\x80\x99s vision and ambition \nattracted major investment from both universities and funders; in 2015, the project had 112 \nuniversity partners and a project budget of over \xe2\x82\xac1 billion (Abbott, 2015).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nYet the project was plagued with problems.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
These problems spanned multiple domains, 

ranging from concerns that the project was monopolizing resources that could be allocated to 
other worthy projects, to disagreement over the project\xe2\x80\x99s core aims, to dissatisfaction with the 
project\xe2\x80\x99s autocratic leadership structure (Abbott, 2014).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Regardless of the specific causes, by \n2015 most scientists agreed that the project was not living up to Henry Markram\xe2\x80\x99s original vision \n(Abbott, 2015).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Markram was removed from his leadership position the following year (Abbott, \n2020).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: The project is still ongoing, but whether it will produce the revolution in neuroscience \nthat Markram promised is anything but clear.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: \n\nMitigating this risk.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
As the example of the Human Brain Project illustrates, mega-

mistakes can emerge due to a failure to manage other risks of big team science, such as the risk 
of mis-management.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Thus, mitigating other risks of big team science may be one useful way of \nmitigating the risks of mega-mistakes.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
However, big team science organizations can also proactively implement quality control 

processes that minimize the risks of mega-mistakes more directly.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
These quality control 
processes entail everything from formally reviewing project proposals, to instituting code 
review, pilot tests, and project \xe2\x80\x9csoft launches\xe2\x80\x9d, to formal methods of optionally stopping data 
collection to avoid overinvestment in bad ideas (Lakens, 2014; Sch\xc3\xb6nbrodt et al., 2017).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Quality \ncontrol can also involve partnering with outside scientific organizations that implement their own \nmethods of quality control, such as journals that administer Registered Reports.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
An additional promising strategy involves instituting audits of scientific processes by 
people who are formally independent of the big team science collaboration.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
These audits can 
take the form of research design review by outside experts, systems of back-translation to check 
the quality of forward-translation, formal code review, and even \xe2\x80\x9cred teams\xe2\x80\x9d who receive 
bounties for spotting bugs and other project flaws (Lakens, 2020).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
All these quality control methods have high value in solo PI projects, but take on renewed 

importance in projects that command resources on the scale of big team science.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
Big team science will never be a wholesale replacement to solo science \xe2\x80\x93 nor should it 

 
be.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Absent the coordination constraints of a large team, solo scientists have the freedom to \nflexibly explore ideas that might be infeasible in a larger group setting without creating a risk of \nsquandering a scale of resources that rises to the level of a \xe2\x80\x9cmega-mistake\xe2\x80\x9d.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
What big team science can do is vastly \xe2\x80\x9cscale up\xe2\x80\x9d the amount of resources \xe2\x80\x93 in other 
words, the money, person-hours, and specialized expertise \xe2\x80\x93 that can be deployed in a single, 

Conclusion 

 

\x0c18 

well-chosen and well-vetted project.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: This increased resource investment can result in projects \nthat are larger, more rigorous, and more representative of humanity.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: We believe this virtue is not \nto be underestimated, as low resource investment is likely a key ultimate cause of why \npsychology\xe2\x80\x99s progress has been slow.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Moreover, other disciplines may find themselves facing \nsimilar problems.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Ecologists identified similar problems in their own discipline, and team \nscience is emerging as a potential solution (Fraser et al., 2013).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: Pre-clinical cancer biology faces \nproblems even conducting the studies needed to assess whether a replicability problem exists \n(Friedl, 2019).
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: A greater focus on big team science may help pre-clinical cancer biology \xe2\x80\x9cscale \nup\xe2\x80\x9d the resources devoted to the typical study in the discipline, which may help lay the \ngroundwork to allow these replication studies to be conducted.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
We believe that big team science has the potential to simultaneously tackle the many 

challenges that psychology faces.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: However, to fulfill this potential, psychological scientists must \nrecognize and manage the many barriers and risks that this approach entails.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence: If properly managed \nto leverage its virtues while mitigating its risks, we believe that big team science can be \ninstrumental in the movement to build more reliable, informative, and rigorous science.
source: Forscher et al. - The Benefits, Barriers, and Risks of Big Team Scie.pdf

sentence:
It is part of a broader movement towards 
grass-roots big-team science: endeavours in 
which an unusually large number of research-
ers \xe2\x80\x94 often dispersed across institutions 
and world regions \xe2\x80\x94 self-organize to pool 
intellectual and material resources in pur-
suit of a common goal4.
source: Coles et al. - 2022 - Build up big-team science.pdf

sentence:
In addition to the 
ManyBabies Consortium, the authors have 
collectively been involved in creating the 
Psychological Science Accelerator (involv-
ing some 1,200\xc2\xa0researchers)5, the Disturbance 
and Resources Across Global Grasslands net-
work (DRAGNet; around 100 researchers; 
https://dragnetglobal.weebly.com) and the 
ManyPrimates project (comprising about 
150\xc2\xa0researchers6; see \xe2\x80\x98Examples of big-team 
science\xe2\x80\x99).
source: Coles et al. - 2022 - Build up big-team science.pdf

sentence:
These self-organized consortia 
pool resources to conduct massive studies in 
psychology, ecology and primatology, respec-
tively.
source: Coles et al. - 2022 - Build up big-team science.pdf

sentence:
They perform collaborative endeav-
ours similar to those of the Human Genome 
Project and groups within CERN, Europe\xe2\x80\x99s 
particle-physics lab near Geneva, Switzer-
land, but have been founded without formal 
funding  mechanisms  or  well-developed 
infrastructure.

We have found that grass-roots big-team 
science is capable of generating knowledge 
that is difficult to obtain \xe2\x80\x94 but faces several 
barriers to sustainability.

Barrier 1: rewarding team players
Michele Grigsby Coffey, a historian at the Uni-
versity of Memphis in Tennessee, has described 
academia as \xe2\x80\x9ca selfish sport\xe2\x80\x9d in which research-
ers \xe2\x80\x9care rewarded for self-absorbed fixations\xe2\x80\x9d, 
and in which \xe2\x80\x9cprioritizing yourself at the 
expense of others is encouraged\xe2\x80\x9d7.
source: Coles et al. - 2022 - Build up big-team science.pdf

sentence:
Big-team 
science, however, is a team sport that often 
requires researchers to prioritize discovery 
over their own self-interests.
source: Coles et al. - 2022 - Build up big-team science.pdf

Barrier 3: funding and sustainability
Despite  well-recognized  outputs,  we  all 
scramble constantly to keep our big-team 
initiatives going.

sentence:
These grass-roots projects 
can be established with little funding, but they 
are difficult to maintain without financial sup-
port.

sentence:
Big-team science needs funds to retain 
researchers who know how to coordinate the 
next wave of science, to support tools for man-
aging increasingly complex workflows, and to 
support participation from researchers who 
are not well resourced.

Scientific Utopia III:  
Crowdsourcing Science

Eric Luis Uhlmann1, Charles R. Ebersole2,  
Christopher R. Chartier3, Timothy M. Errington4
Mallory C. Kidwell5, Calvin K. Lai6, Randy J. McCarthy7,  
Amy Riegelman8, Raphael Silberzahn9, and  
Brian A. Nosek2,4
1Organizational Behaviour Area, INSEAD, Singapore; 2Department of Psychology, University of Virginia; 
3Department of Psychology, Ashland University; 4Center for Open Science, Charlottesville, Virginia; 5Department 
of Psychology, University of Utah; 6Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences, Washington University in 
St.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Louis; 7Center for the Study of Family Violence and Sexual Assault, Northern Illinois University; 8University 
Libraries, University of Minnesota; and 9Department of Business and Management, University of Sussex

,  

Abstract
Most scientific research is conducted by small teams of investigators who together formulate hypotheses, collect data, 
conduct analyses, and report novel findings.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: These teams operate independently as vertically integrated silos.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: Here \nwe argue that scientific research that is horizontally distributed can provide substantial complementary value, aiming \nto  maximize  available  resources,  promote  inclusiveness  and  transparency,  and  increase  rigor  and  reliability.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: This \nalternative approach enables researchers to tackle ambitious projects that would not be possible under the standard \nmodel.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: Crowdsourced scientific initiatives vary in the degree of communication between project members from largely \nindependent work curated by a coordination team to crowd collaboration on shared activities.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: The potential benefits \nand challenges of large-scale collaboration span the entire research process: ideation, study design, data collection, \ndata analysis, reporting, and peer review.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Complementing traditional small science with crowdsourced approaches can 
accelerate the progress of science and improve the quality of scientific research.

Keywords
crowdsourcing, collaboration, teams, methodology, metascience

There  is  no  perfect  study.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: Scientists,  in  their  effort  to \nunderstand  nature,  are  constrained  by  limited  time, \nresources, and expertise.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
This constraint may produce a 
dilemma between choosing a lower quality, expedient 
approach or conducting a better powered, more inten-
sive investigation allowing for stronger inferences.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Ideals 
of  the  scientific  process  can  be  outweighed  by  the 
pragmatic reality of scientists\xe2\x80\x99 available resources and 
pursuit of career advancement.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: Scientists are rewarded \nfor  being  the  originators  of  new  ideas  and  evidence \nthrough the authorship of articles.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
These cultural incen-
tives  foster  a  focus  on  novelty  and  authorship  that  
can come at the expense of rigor and foster question-
able  practices  (Bakker,  van  Dijk,  &  Wicherts,  2012;  
Greenland & Fontanarosa, 2012; Nosek, Spies, & Motyl, 
2012; Open Science Collaboration, 2015).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
One alterna-
tive is for researchers to take more time for individual 

studies, expend more resources on each project, and 
publish fewer findings.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: Scientists could also work more \ncollectively, combining resources across more contribu-\ntors.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
But such choices have implications for productiv-
ity, individual credit, and career advancement.

Here  we  consider  the  standard  model  of  scientific 
investigation and describe a complementary model\xe2\x80\x94
crowdsourcing science.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Crowdsourced approaches seek 
to  maximize  the  use  of  available  resources,  diversify

contributions, enable big science, and increase trans-

source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
The adaptation of cultural norms 
and incentives to promote crowdsourcing as a comple-
ment to the standard model promises to make science 
more rigorous and inclusive and accelerate discovery.

Two Models of Doing Science
Standard model: vertical integration
Some  academic  research  resembles  a  vertically  inte-
grated business.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
An individual or small research team 
conceives a research question, designs studies to inves-
tigate  the  question,  implements  the  studies,  analyzes 
the data, and writes a report of what was found.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: The \nclosed team conducts the entire process from conceiv-\ning  the  idea  to  reporting  the  outcomes.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
The  team  
members responsible for these steps are active collabo-
rators  and  coauthors  on  a  manuscript  reporting  the 
research.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
The  sought-after  reward  is  acceptance  and 
publication  in  the  most  widely  read  and  prominent 
journal possible.

This model has several notable characteristics.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
It is 
localized,  with  funding  distributed  to  particular  labs 
and institutions, and resource intensive, with the project 
work divided among a few individuals.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Access to pro-
ductive research pipelines is constrained, and experi-
ence  and  status  lead  to  opportunities  to  engage  in 
research collaborations (Merton, 1968).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
It produces a 
large  quantity  of  small  science  with  teams  of  limited 
size conducting projects that are correspondingly lim-
ited in scope\xe2\x80\x94a small team can collect only so much 
data,  carry  out  only  so  many  analyses,  and  consider 
only so many alternatives to their methodology.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Finally, 
contribution  is  recognized  and  rewarded  through 
authorship on the final publication.

The standard model is akin to the philosopher model 
of scholarly contribution.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: An independent thinker con-\nceives and generates a stand-alone piece of scholarship.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
After  peer  review  by  a  small  number  of  select  col-
leagues,  that  scholarship  is  entered  into  the  market-
place of ideas for others to examine, discuss, critique, 
and extend.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Independence in developing and enacting 
the idea allows the scholar to dig deeply into a question 
or  idea  without  interference,  and  credit  allocation  is 
straightforward.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: Scholars are evaluated on the basis of \nthe  reception  of  their  work  in  the  idea  marketplace.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Outstanding ideas and evidence may become perma-
nently linked to the scholar\xe2\x80\x99s identity, securing a lasting 
reputation and impact.

So what is wrong with the standard approach to sci-
ence?
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: For many research questions and contributions, \nnothing.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Independently generated contributions are an 
efficient  means  of  getting  initial  evidence  for  many 

ideas into the marketplace.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Indeed, the decentralized 
nature of science is presumed to feed the productive 
generation  and  culling  of  ideas  by  the  independent 
actions of scholars with different priors, assumptions, 
expertise, and interests.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: Small teams often work together \nrepeatedly  and  develop  cospecializations  that  enable \ndeep dives into a methodology or phenomenon.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
A com-
munity  of  scientists  then  shares  its  work,  exchanges 
feedback, and serially builds on each other\xe2\x80\x99s findings.
At the same time, for some research questions and 
contributions, the standard model may limit progress.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: \nIndividual researchers and small teams must consider \ncertain trade-offs when directing their research efforts.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
They  could  vary  design  elements  and  stimuli  instead 
of  holding  them  constant,  collect  larger  samples  for 
fewer studies instead of smaller samples for more stud-
ies, and they could replicate their findings across mul-
tiple conditions or contexts rather than demonstrate a 
phenomenon and then move on.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: Researchers inevitably \nweigh  these  trade-offs  against  the  potential  rewards.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
And because the present culture prizes innovation and 
discovery  (Bakker  et\xc2\xa0 al.,  2012),  some  behaviors  that 
would foster research credibility and cumulative prog-
ress are performed ineffectively or infrequently.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Under-
performed  behaviors  include  collecting  large, 
cross-cultural samples to evaluate generalizability and 
estimate  effect  sizes  precisely  (Henrich,  Heine,  & 
Norenzayan, 2010), replicating findings systematically 
in independent laboratories (Klein et\xc2\xa0al., 2014; Makel, 
Plucker,  &  Hegarty,  2012;  Mueller-Langer,  Fecher,  
Harhoff, & Wagner, 2019; Simons, 2014), obtaining sev-
eral different perspectives on how to analyze the same 
data (Silberzahn et\xc2\xa0al., 2018), and using a wide variety 
of study designs and stimuli ( Judd, Westfall, & Kenny, 
2012; Wells & Windschitl, 1999).

Alternative model: horizontal distribution
The alternate model\xe2\x80\x94crowdsourcing\xe2\x80\x94eschews vertical 
integration and embraces the horizontal distribution of 
ownership, resources, and expertise (Howe, 2006).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
In 
a distributed collaboration, numerous researchers each 
carry out specific components of a larger project, usu-
ally  under  the  direction  of  a  core  coordination  team 
(such that crowd projects are rarely perfectly horizon-
tally distributed).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Modern science is already stretching 
the  standard  model  in  more  collaborative  directions 
(see Supplement 1 in the Supplemental Material avail-
able online).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: Solo authorship is now the exception in \nmost fields.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: This is partly due to the diversification of \nexpertise  required  to  conduct  research  with  modern \ntools (B\xc3\xb6rner et\xc2\xa0al., 2010).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Across disciplines, team size 
almost  doubled  from  1.9  in  the  1960s  to  3.5  in  2005 

\x0cCrowdsourcing Science 

713

(Valderas et\xc2\xa0al., 2007; Wuchty, Jones, & Uzzi, 2007), and 
working in teams is associated with greater individual 
career success (Kniffin & Hanks, 2018).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Team-authored 
articles are more cited than solo-authored articles, and 
this  gap  in  scholarly  impact  has  increased  over  time 
(Valderas et\xc2\xa0al., 2007; Wuchty et\xc2\xa0al., 2007).

Rather  than  two  qualitatively  distinct  categories  of 
research, the vertically integrated and horizontally dis-
tributed approaches are better conceived as a contin-
uum, with variation in the depth of contribution by any 
given individual and the number of individuals contrib-
uting to the project.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
New opportunities and challenges 
emerge  when  moving  further  across  the  continuum 
from  singular,  independent  scholars  to  a  distributed, 
interdependent  community.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Crowdsourcing  carefully 
selected research questions, in parallel to the necessar-
ily  far  greater  number  of  small  team  projects,  holds 
several potential benefits for science, among which are 
enabling the conduct of large-scale research projects, 
democratizing who contributes to science, and assess-
ing the robustness of findings.

Enabling big science.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
An inclusive, diversified contri-
bution model enables ambitious projects that would be 
unattainable  by  individuals  or  small  teams  working  in 
isolation.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: Combining  resources  enables  crowdsourced \nteams to enact research designs that vastly exceed what \ncould be accomplished locally.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Instead of holding sam-
pling,  stimulus,  or  procedural  variables  constant  and 
hoping  they  do  not  matter,  crowdsourced  teams  can 
allow them to vary and test whether they do.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Instead of 
carrying  out  a  low-powered,  imprecise  test,  crowd-
sourced teams can conduct high-powered, precise stud-
ies  and  draw  confident  conclusions.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Crowdsourcing 
complex activities seeks to mobilize the crowd\xe2\x80\x99s compe-
tencies, knowledge, and skills and may leverage under-
used resources such as a better way to analyze the data, 
access  to  hard-to-recruit  populations,  knowledge  of 
unpublished research or articles published in other lan-
guages,  and  translation  of  research  materials  into  local 
languages  and  dialects.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Crowdsourcing  flips  research 
planning  from  \xe2\x80\x9cwhat  is  the  best  we  can  do  with  the 
resources we have to investigate our question?\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cwhat 
is the best way to investigate our question, so that we can 
decide what resources to recruit?\xe2\x80\x9d

Democratizing  science.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Although  personal  factors 
(Clemente, 1973; Hirsch, 2007; Williamson & Cable, 2003) 
and  merit  play  a  role  in  success  in  science,  scientific 
careers  also  exhibit  a  Matthew  effect  (Merton,  1968).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Early advantages in doctoral institution rank, professional 
connections, and grant funding accumulate benefits over 
time (Bol, De Vaan, & van de Rijt, 2018; Clauset, Arbesman,  
&  Larremore,  2015).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Grant  funding  is  overallocated  to 

elite universities, and evidence suggests that returns on 
investment would be greater if the funds were distributed 
more evenly (Wahls, 2018).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Early-career researchers from 
less  well-known  institutions,  underrepresented  demo-
graphic groups, and countries that lack economic resources 
may never have a fair chance to compete (Petersen, Jung, 
Yang, & Stanley, 2011; Wahls, 2018).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Academic fields are 
generally rich in talent, such that globally distributed proj-
ects  can  recruit  individuals  with  advanced  training  and 
much to offer yet too few resources to enact the vertical 
model competitively on their own.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Few people enjoy the 
resource benefits of research-intensive institutions, includ-
ing laboratory space, professional staff to support grant 
writing and management, graduate students, light teach-
ing loads, and a community of colleagues for developing 
ideas and sharing infrastructure.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Crowdsourcing aims to 
provide  a  new  avenue  through  which  those  outside  of 
major research institutions can contribute to high-profile 
projects, increasing inclusiveness, merit, and returns on 
investment (Chargaff, 1978; Feyerabend, 1982).

Assessing the robustness of findings.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: A crowdsour ced \napproach is uniquely advantaged in determining the\xc2\xa0reli-\nability and generalizability of findings.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
The ecosystem of 
standard science leads to the publication of massive num-
bers of small-sample studies (Pan, Petersen, Pammolli, & 
Fortunato, 2016), each with observations typically drawn 
from a single population (e.g., undergraduates from the 
researchers\xe2\x80\x99  home  institution  in  the  case  of  behavioral 
experiments; Sears, 1986).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Combined with the filter of an 
academic  review  process  that  primarily  permits  statisti-
cally significant results to appear in the published record 
(Fanelli, 2010), the end result is a research literature filled 
with inaccurately estimated effect sizes as a result of pub-
lication bias (Ioannidis, 2005, 2008).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
The standard approach 
to  science  is  also  susceptible  to  issues  such  as  study 
designs  generated  from  a  single  theoretical  perspective 
(Monin, Pizarro, & Beer, 2007), unconsidered cultural dif-
ferences (Henrich et\xc2\xa0al., 2010), and researcher degrees of 
freedom in data analysis (Gelman & Loken, 2014; Simmons, 
Nelson,  &  Simonsohn,  2011).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Large-scale  collaboration 
helped transform epi demiology into a more reliable field 
(Ioannidis, Tarone, & McLaughlin, 2011; Panagiotou, Willer, 
Hirschhorn,  &  Ioannidis,  2013),  and  this  process  is  cur-
rently under way in psychology and other scientific disci-
plines.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf
Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Crowdsourcing research is a part of a 
changing  landscape  of  science  that  seeks  to  improve 
research  reliability  and  advance  the  credibility  of  academic 
research (LeBel, McCarthy, Earp, Elson, & Vanpaemel, 2018; 
Nosek et\xc2\xa0al., 2012).

\x0c714 

Uhlmann et al.

At  the  same  time,  there  are  opportunity  costs  and 
diminishing returns involved in organizing many labo-
ratories  to  carry  out  a  single  scientific  investigation.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: \nOrganizing a collective for a globally distributed project \ncan create bureaucracy and transaction costs.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
For the 
same effort, a larger number of ideas with initial sup-
porting evidence could have been introduced into the 
literature by smaller teams working separately.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Crowd-
sourcing  allows  for  systematically  examining  cross-
population variability, but it is important to begin by 
making sure the effect emerges reliably in at least one 
location.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: It will often be beneficial to rely on research \nfrom small teams for these reasons, especially when it \ncomes  to  new  areas  of  inquiry.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Crowd  projects  with 
dozens or even hundreds of authors also create credit 
ambiguity and lack extrinsic incentives for participation, 
topics we address in depth later when we discuss struc-
tural reforms to encourage greater crowdsourcing.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
We 
believe the two models should coexist, with individual 
investigators  and  small  teams  generating  initial  evi-
dence  for  new  ideas  and  crowdsourced  initiatives 
implemented to select particularly critical questions for 
intense examination.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
A diverse array of scientific proj-
ects,  everywhere  along  the  continuum  from  lone 
researchers to huge collectives, may produce the great-
est  return  of  useful  knowledge  from  the  resources 
invested.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
The remainder of this article discusses circum-
stances in which crowdsourcing offers particular oppor-
tunities and challenges as a complement to the standard 
model.

Forms of Scientific Crowdsourcing
Rather than supplanting the standard approach, orga-
nizing  many  individuals  and  laboratories  into  shared 
projects  seeks  to  offset  some  of  the  weaknesses  of 
vertically integrated science.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Crowd initiatives vary on 
multiple  dimensions  that  can  create  advantages  and 
disadvantages depending on the research application 
(Lakhani, Jeppesen, Lohse, & Panetta, 2007; Muffatto, 
2006;  Salganik,  2017;  Srinarayan,  Sugumaran,  &  
Rajagopalan,  2002;  Surowiecki,  2005).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
For  example, 
crowdsourced projects vary in terms of the degree of 
communication between project members, from largely 
independent work curated by a coordination team to 
crowd collaboration on shared activities.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Crowd-science 
initiatives also vary in their inclusivity, from open calls 
for  collaborators  to  carefully  chosen  groups  of  topic 
experts.

Figure 1 crosses the horizontal dimension of com-
munication (anchored at the left end by curated con-
tributions and at the right by crowd collaboration) with 
the vertical dimension of selectivity to create a 2 \xc3\x97 2 
matrix.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: Examples of relevant crowdsourced projects are \n\nplaced in this matrix as illustrations.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
These projects are 
described in greater detail in the next section and in 
Tables 1 and 2 (see also Supplements 1 and 2 in the 
Supplemental Material).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Citizen-science initiatives that 
include anyone willing to collect data involve a high 
degree of independence between actors and thus fall 
into  the  bottom-left  quadrant  (Gura,  2013).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Posing  a 
research question to specialists (e.g., moral-judgment 
researchers) and asking them to independently design 
studies to test the same idea falls into the top-left quad-
rant  (Landy  et\xc2\xa0 al.,  2018).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Iterative  contests  in  which 
topic experts work together to improve experimental 
interventions (Lai et\xc2\xa0al., 2014) and the collective devel-
opment of open-source software (Muffatto, 2006) are 
in the top-right quadrant, and more inclusive forms of 
crowd writing (Christensen & van Bever, 2014) are in 
the bottom-right quadrant.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Open peer review, in which 
anyone  can  publicly  comment  on  a  scientific  manu-
script  or  article,  falls  into  the  bottom-right  quadrant, 
and  crowd  review  by  experts  carefully  chosen  by  a 
journal editor falls into the top-right quadrant.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Tradi-
tional small-team research, with unrestricted commu-
nication  and  select  membership,  falls  outside  the 
extreme top-right corner of the matrix at the far end of 
both axes.

Multistage projects may operate in different locations 
in this space during the research life cycle.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: For example, \nto explore consensus building about disparate findings \nfrom the same data set, Silberzahn et\xc2\xa0al.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: (2018) segued \nfrom isolated individual work to round-robin feedback \nand  then  open-group  debate.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Indeed,  much  crowd-
sourced science moves gradually from left to right on 
the communication dimension over the life course of 
the project, culminating in collective e-mail exchanges 
and  editing  of  the  manuscript  draft.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Likewise,  crowd 
projects tend to rely more on selective expertise over 
time (i.e., move up the vertical axis), as project coor-
dinators and specialized subteams of statistical experts 
check the collective work for errors and play leading 
roles in producing the final report.

On the vertical dimension, greater inclusivity facili-
tates  scaling  up  for  massive  initiatives.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence: In  contrast, \nselectivity  in  project  membership  prioritizes  specific \nareas of expertise for contribution.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
It is not yet clear 
under what conditions involving large crowds of con-
tributors (i.e., moving downward on the vertical axis) 
compromises overall project quality relative to applying 
mild  or  strong  selectivity  standards  for  contribution 
(Budescu & Chen, 2015; Mannes, Soll, & Larrick, 2014).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

2004; Salter et\xc2\xa0al., 2014; Westra et\xc2\xa0al., 2011), and the 
quality-quantity trade-off that can accompany scaling

on  relevant  skill  sets.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Testing  the  conditions  under 
which crowdsourcing increases and decreases project 
quality will inform future investments in crowdsourced 
research.

In contrast, there is little direct evidence regarding 
the  consequences  of  information  exchange  between 
project members in crowdsourced scientific initiatives.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
Nevertheless,  potential  costs  and  benefits  of  crowd 
communication are suggested by the literature on group 
influence and decision making.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
One of the virtues of 
crowds of independent agents, especially demographi-
cally and intellectually diverse ones, is their tendency 

\x0c720 

Uhlmann et al.

to  balance  out  individual  biases  and  errors  in  the  
aggregate (Galton, 1907; Larrick, Mannes, & Soll, 2012;  
Surowiecki, 2005).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

1) may help 
to  avoid  the  potentially  biasing  effect  of  individuals\xe2\x80\x99

Reich, 2010; Luborsky et\xc2\xa0al., 1999; Manzoli et\xc2\xa0al., 2014;

The 
effectiveness of crowds is more difficult to evaluate in

Yet  even  then,  the 
diversity in approaches and results on the part of inde-
pendent scientists, for example in analytic choices and 
study designs, is at least made transparent to the reader 
(Landy et\xc2\xa0al., 2018; Silberzahn et\xc2\xa0al., 2018).

That  the \xe2\x80\x9cwisdom  of  the  crowd\xe2\x80\x9d  effect  is  spoiled 
when peer influence between members of the crowd 
is  possible  (Lorenz,  Rauhut,  Schweitzer,  &  Helbing, 
2011) suggests that the more one moves toward crowd 
collaborations  (i.e.,  right  on  the  horizontal  axis),  the 
more  conformity  and  deference  to  authority  become

source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

The one crowdsourced project that has tracked 
individual beliefs under conditions of gradually increas-
ing  communication  found  little  evidence  of  conver-
gence over time, beyond what would be expected from 
sensitivity  to  new  evidence  (see  Fig.

sentence: 4  in  Silberzahn \net\xc2\xa0al., 2018).
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
The circumstances under which conformity 
effects occur in crowd science remains an open empiri-
cal  question,  and  future  projects  should  consider 
manipulating factors such as task interdependence and 
anonymity of communications.

Allowing information exchange and creating inter-
dependencies  between  project  members  also  comes 
with potential important benefits.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf

sentence:
One of the hypoth-
esized benefits of crowd collaboration is the ability of 
members of the community to learn from each other 
(Wenger,  1998).

sentence: For  example,  teams  in  the  Lai  et\xc2\xa0 al.

sentence:
(2014) intervention contest observed the effectiveness 
of others\xe2\x80\x99 interventions between rounds and used those 
insights to improve their own interventions.

sentence:
Likewise, 
the  round-robin  feedback  between  different  analytic 
teams  in  the  crowdsourcing  data-analysis  initiative  
(Silberzahn et\xc2\xa0al., 2018) helped several analysts to iden-
tify  clear  errors  and  adopt  improved  specifications.
source: Uhlmann et al. - Scientific Utopia III Crowdsourcing Science.pdf
